quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 6 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 6.7: Identity Matrix and Inverse
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Properties of I and the existence of A⁻¹

questions.question: Which of the following describes an Identity Matrix?
options: A square matrix with 1s on the main diagonal and 0s elsewhere.
A matrix that, when added to A, results in A.
A matrix with more rows than columns.
questions.explanation: The Identity matrix acts as the '1' of matrix multiplication.

questions.question: What is the result of $A \cdot A^{-1}$?
questions.explanation: By definition, multiplying a matrix by its inverse results in the multiplicative identity.

questions.question: A matrix that does NOT have an inverse is called:
questions.explanation: Singular matrices have a determinant of zero and cannot be inverted.

questions.question: To have an inverse, a matrix MUST be:
questions.explanation: Only square matrices can have inverses because the relationship $AA^{-1} = A^{-1}A = I$ requires compatible dimensions in both directions.

questions.question: In the $2 \times 2$ inverse formula, what is the term $(ad - bc)$ called?
questions.explanation: The determinant determines if an inverse exists; if it is zero, you'd be dividing by zero, which is undefined.

questions.question: What is the inverse of the Identity matrix $I$?
questions.explanation: Since $I \cdot I = I$, the identity matrix is its own inverse.

questions.question: When finding the inverse of $A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}$, what happens to the elements $a$ and $d$?
options: They stay put but change signs.
questions.explanation: In the $2 \times 2$ shortcut, you swap the main diagonal elements ($a$ and $d$) and negate the off-diagonal elements ($b$ and $c$).

questions.question: True or False: If $AB = I$, then $B$ is the inverse of $A$.
questions.explanation: This is the definition of the inverse matrix.

questions.question:
Which of these matrices is singular? 
$A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$ 
$B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$
questions.explanation: For matrix A, $(1)(4) - (2)(2) = 4 - 4 = 0$. Since the determinant is 0, it is singular.

questions.question: Is it true that $(AB)^{-1} = A^{-1}B^{-1}$?
options: Only if A and B are identical.
questions.explanation: The 'Shoes and Socks' rule: when inverting a product, you must reverse the order of the matrices.

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You've mastered the 'multiplicative 1' of matrices.
scoreMessages.70: Good work. Remember: no determinant, no inverse!
scoreMessages.50: Practice the $2 \times 2$ inverse shortcut to build speed.
scoreMessages.0: Review the definition of the Identity matrix and the $2 \times 2$ inverse formula.
